DOC.HEAD: Bani-Sadr Says Waite In Hands Of Iranian Secret Service
DOC.TEXT: Iran's former president, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, said Monday he believes Iranian secret service agents are holding British hostage Terry Waite, either in Lebanon or Iran. Bani-Sadr, who was the Islamic Republic's first president but has lived in exile in France since 1981, said in an interview that friends in Iran told him Waite had been ``in a safe place, in security for several months in the hands of the Iranian secret services.'' He said he believed this could be a sign that negotiations for release of Waite and other Western hostages seized in Lebanon could be making progress. Waite, 50, the special envoy of Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie, disappeared in Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987, while on a mission to try to free Western hostages. No group has claimed to hold him, but he is widely believed to be held by Islamic Jihad. Waite is one of 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. Longest held is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.
